thread.title: History Shows Snow Is Just Around The Corner
thread.title_full: History Shows Snow Is Just Around The Corner

title: History Shows Snow Is Just Around The Corner
text:
History Shows Snow Is Just Around The Corner October 20, 2015, 6:11 PM by Scot Mundt SIOUX FALLS, SD - 
While temperatures don't show it, KELOLAND can easily whip up snow this time of year. 
The average first measurable snow, which is considered a tenth of an inch or more, occurs on October 20 for Rapid City. Sooner in the Hills, with an average date of September 29 in Lead. 
Other first measurable snow in South Dakota usually waits until the last couple of days of October into the first week of November. They include October 30 for Aberdeen and Mobridge, November 1 in Huron, and November 3 in Sioux Falls. It's a little later in Yankton with an average first snow date on November 11. 
While temperatures will cool this week, we're keeping snow out of the forecast. But, with a stronger blast of cold air around midweek next week, we'll see if we can generate some in the Hills of western South Dakota. There are some models hinting at that. Â© 2015 KELOLAND TV. All Rights Reserved.
